content:
lass="word-wrap-span">MARK lass="word-wrap-span">WARNER, a lass="word-wrap-span">Democrat who is running for a third term as Virginia’s senior US senator in 2020, is unlikely to repeat the mistake that nearly cost him his seat in 2014: ignoring his party’s increasingly liberal base.

Having lass="word-wrap-span">coasted to his first term in 2008, in part because of the business-oriented lass="word-wrap-span">bipartisanship on which he was elected governor seven years earlier, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner recycled his policy-before-politics message against Ed lass="word-wrap-span">Gillespie, a veteran Washington lass="word-wrap-span">fixer. By doing that, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner missed a chance to generate lass="word-wrap-span">enthusiasm among the state’s expanding lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic base. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Gillespie came within roughly 17,000 votes of defeating Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner, a mobile-communications multimillionaire.

lass="word-wrap-span">Political near-death has a way of focusing the mind. As he tip-toes toward a re-election bid—Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner has yet to lass="word-wrap-span">formally lass="word-wrap-span">announce but is lass="word-wrap-span">avidly raising money—he is lass="word-wrap-span">accommodating left-leaning lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats who lass="word-wrap-span">dominate the party with a measured embrace of some of their priorities, including easing the student debt lass="word-wrap-span">crisis. lass="word-wrap-span">When Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner ran for governor in 2001 he promised to oppose any new gun control laws; he is now taking a tougher line on firearms. lass="word-wrap-span">That stance has also been shaped by two mass shootings in his home state. In the most recent lass="word-wrap-span">atrocity, in lass="word-wrap-span">May, a lass="word-wrap-span">gunman lass="word-wrap-span">killed 12 people in the resort city of Virginia lass="word-wrap-span">Beach.

Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner is getting a help from an unlikely source: lass="word-wrap-span">President lass="word-wrap-span">Donald lass="word-wrap-span">Trump. As the senior lass="word-wrap-span">Democrat on the lass="word-wrap-span">Senate lass="word-wrap-span">Intelligence lass="word-wrap-span">Committee, which continues to lass="word-wrap-span">investigate lass="word-wrap-span">Russia’s attack on the 2016 election, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner is a thorn in the lass="word-wrap-span">President’s side. lass="word-wrap-span">This month he said he still hoped to secure testimony from witnesses who lass="word-wrap-span">cooperated with Robert Mueller’s investigation but not with the lass="word-wrap-span">Committee.

Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s enduring unpopularity in Virginia, the only lass="word-wrap-span">Southern state he lass="word-wrap-span">failed to carry against Hillary Clinton, magnifies Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner’s broad popularity. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s lass="word-wrap-span">approval rating in Virginia has barely lass="word-wrap-span">budged from about 35%. lass="word-wrap-span">Ahead of a visit by Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump on July 30th to lass="word-wrap-span">Jamestown, Virginia, site of the first permanent lass="word-wrap-span">English settlement in lass="word-wrap-span">America in 1607, where he spoke in observance of the 400th anniversary of representative government in lass="word-wrap-span">America, the lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic legislative leadership staged a lass="word-wrap-span">boycott of the president’s appearance.

Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner may not face much competition next year. So far, only one lass="word-wrap-span">Republican has declared for the party’s nomination: lass="word-wrap-span">Scott lass="word-wrap-span">Taylor, a former lass="word-wrap-span">congressman from the defence-rich southeastern corner of the state. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Taylor, a swaggering former navy lass="word-wrap-span">SEAL with an lass="word-wrap-span">incandescent smile, was swept from office in 2018 after a single term by an anti-lass="word-wrap-span">Trump tsunami. In his lass="word-wrap-span">announcement video, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Taylor didn’t even mention his lass="word-wrap-span">Republican lass="word-wrap-span">affiliation, though lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats have pointed out his record of voting with the president.

In a high-turnout, presidential year, Virginia’s lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic reflex could be robust, helping Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner and his seven lass="word-wrap-span">congressional running mates. lass="word-wrap-span">Still, given his lass="word-wrap-span">innate lass="word-wrap-span">centrist tendencies that lass="word-wrap-span">Still lass="word-wrap-span">beguile the occasional moderate lass="word-wrap-span">Republican, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner is wary of the cross-currents of presidential politics. He has yet to make an lass="word-wrap-span">endorsement for the nomination. It is difficult lass="word-wrap-span">envisioning him easily finding common ground with the party’s more liberal candidates, especially those whose seemingly profligate proposals—government health care for all and free public college—are lass="word-wrap-span">inconsistent with his reputation as a lass="word-wrap-span">fiscal lass="word-wrap-span">hawk.

Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner can meanwhile lass="word-wrap-span">affirm his partisan lass="word-wrap-span">credentials in the policy realm—specifically, as a member of the intelligence committee—by highlighting Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s perceived lass="word-wrap-span">accommodation of lass="word-wrap-span">Russia, its attack on the 2016 campaign and lass="word-wrap-span">Republican resistance to calls by Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner and others to shield lass="word-wrap-span">America’s electoral system from further foreign lass="word-wrap-span">interference.

lass="word-wrap-span">This is an unexpected role for Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner. He became the lass="word-wrap-span">Committee’s lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic vice-chairman by accident, when lass="word-wrap-span">Diane Feinstein of lass="word-wrap-span">California gave up the seat to join the lass="word-wrap-span">Senate lass="word-wrap-span">Judiciary lass="word-wrap-span">Committee. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner’s lass="word-wrap-span">assignment overseeing the world of spies, shadow lass="word-wrap-span">diplomacy and cyber-lass="word-wrap-span">espionage has allowed him to develop an unlikely skill set for a politician whose background in business has made him a voice on taxation, finance and regulation.

In Virginia, meanwhile, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner wants to focus on helping home-state lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats. lass="word-wrap-span">This year, the state holds state legislative elections in which lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats hope to take back the lass="word-wrap-span">General lass="word-wrap-span">Assembly. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner has taken on many of the fund-raising and voter-mobilisation duties that would ordinarily fall to Ralph Northam, the governor, who was lass="word-wrap-span">battered by a black face scandal in February.

In filling in for the governor, along with lass="word-wrap-span">Tim lass="word-wrap-span">Kaine, Virginia’s other lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic senator, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Warner is simultaneously building up his own political lass="word-wrap-span">apparatus, identifying organisers and activists who could be effective in next year’s campaign.
